hackathon-description-text: HackPrinceton invites you to explore the universe. For 36 hours on April 1st-3rd, HackPrinceton will bring together 500 developers and designers to create incredible software and hardware projects. Meet fellow hackers, learn new technologies, and hone your skills along seasoned mentors. Whether you're making your first mobile app or are ready to jump onboard the most developed hardware track in the country, join us for 36 glorious hours of hacking.
hackathon-requirements:
Submissions are due on Devpost 
You must include videos, photos, or screenshots of the working product and a link to the source code (GitHub, etc.) of your project.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Awarded to the best software or hardware project overall.
Push the limits of technology with a unique, ambitious, and technically interesting project.
A project that delivers a polished, well-thought-out user experience.
Awarded to the project deemed most original.
The best hardware hack that makes use of wearable technology.
The best hardware hack that makes use of Internet of Things technology.
The best hardware hack that builds on top of our Vex Robotics kits, Gazebo kits, or other robotics parts in our lab.
The best hardware hack with a space-related theme.
For the team who best demonstrates new skills acquired during the hackathon. To qualify, more than half the team must be comprised of first-time hackathon participants.
For the best native mobile app overall.
Visualize, analyze, or represent data in an interesting and beautiful way.
"Houston, we have a problem." For the team with the most spectacular last-minute flop.
Arduino Starter Kits for the team.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of Cloud Services - Sponsored by Linode

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: $250 Amazon gift certificate for each team member.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of the Nessie API - Sponsored by Capital One

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Raspberry Pi + $100 visa gift card + 1 year of Wolfram|Alpha Pro + 1 year of Wolfram Development Platform for each member.
Awarded to support further development of a promising project. To qualify, your team must also apply for the Thiel Fellowship.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Hack to Continue - Sponsored by Thiel Foundation

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Dell 1TB hard drive for each team member.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of AWS - Sponsored by MLH

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Domain.com swag bag for each team member.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Use of Domain.com - Sponsored by MLH

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Github Octocat for each team member.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Developer Tool - Sponsored by MLH

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: To qualify, you must host your project on a .TECH domain name.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Project on .TECH Domain - Sponsored by .TECH

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: For the most ambitious project.
Awarded to the project closest to being launchable as a real product.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Most Launchable - Sponsored by Dorm Room Fund

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Rewards those who tap into a publicly-available source of data, and transform, analyze, or visualize it to provide the general public with valuable, easily understood information that somehow betters their lives. Winners must primarily code Python, use public and open datasets, and create a hack that facilitates the every day lives of the general public. $500 for the team.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: PrincetonPy / PICSciE Prize for Every Day Data for Tomorrow

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Awarded to the project with the greatest potential to make an impact and change the world. $500 for the team.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Most Socially Impactful - Sponsored by Princeton ReachOut

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: $200 (per team) to help your home high school host a hackathon + all-expense paid trips to IgniteSTEM + invites to afterparty at Google NYC HQ.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Education Hack - Sponsored by IgniteSTEM

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=William St & Olden St, Princeton, NJ 08540, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: How original is the idea? Is it simply a repackaging of a previous project or is it something that has never been done before? Projects can also blend two concepts together in a refreshing new way.
Does the project take on technical challenges? What parts of the project did your team invent, and how did you build upon existing tools and technologies?
Does it feel like a quickly hacked-together project, or something that is well thought out? Is the user experience and interface smooth and well-designed?
Is the project zany, interesting or just plain amusing? Will it bring a smile to the face of those who see it, whether they are adults, teenagers or little kids?
Can this hack be used in real life to better somebody's life? Is it enough to justify people wanting to use it?

hackathon-location-address: William St & Olden St, Princeton, NJ 08540, USA
hackathon-description-header: Explore with us. Build out-of-this-world projects at Princeton's 36-hour hackathon.
